bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harry Clemons, November 28, 1939

div1.p: Kean mentions to Clemons his book review of “William Crawford Gorgas: His Life and Work,” and states that the book clearly indicates Gorgas as the originator of methods to eradicate mosquitoes, when in fact Howard was responsible for these measures. Kean is quite upset over the unwillingness of the author of the book to change the facts. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Harry Clemons, November 28, 1939
div1.opener:
2804 N St. n.w.
Washington. D.C.
Nov. 28, 1939.
Mr. Harry Clemons, Librarian, Univ. Va.
My dear Mr. Clemons.
div1.p:
I would like to add to the Walter Reed
file of MSS in the Library an editorial book review
of the biography William Crawford Gorgas: His life and
work, by Marie D. Gorgas and Burton J. Hendrick
Garden City N. Y. Doubleday, Page & Co. 1924.
It has an important bearing on Walter Reed's work
on yellow fever as you will see from the follow-
ing statement. Some months before my retire-
ment, while I was Chief Surgeon First Corps Area stationed
at Boston, I received in the same mail (March 30, 1924)
two letters, one from the Surgeon General of the Army,
Gen. Ireland, the other from Mrs. Walter Reed, both com-
plaining of an article which had just appeared in the
magazine The World's Work. It was a chapter from a
biography of Gorgas then being written by Burton J.
Hendrick and Mrs. Gorgas, in which was given a very
brief and imperfect account of the work of the Reed
Board in Cuba in 1900-1901 and the subsequent work
of Gorgas against mosquitoes in Havana beginning
in March 1901. It stated that when Reed had
demonstrated the fact that mosquitoes were the carriers
Walter Reed & Yellow Fever
2.
of yellow fever it seemed to him just a laboratory
demonstration that did not lead anywhere, as he
did not know any way of combatting this tiny
winged enemy, and things looked as hopely
as ever, until Gorgas came along and by his success-
ful warfare against the mosquito, became the real
demonstrator of the fact that yellow fever was a
mosquito-borne disease! Both the Surgeon General
and Mrs. Reed declared that I was the person to
take the matter up with Mr. Hendrick and obtain
an authoritative correction of this astonishing mis-
statement. This was an easy thing to do. Reed had
announced his findings in a paper read at the
Pan American Medical Congress which met at
Havana Feb. 4th 1901, and ended it with eleven
conclusions, none of which has been shaken to this
day. The 10th conclusion was as follows:

10. “The spread of yellow fever can be most effectually
controlled by measures directed to the destruction of
mosquitoes and the protection of the sick against the
bites of these insects.” The older army medical
officers in Cuba were quite familiar with the means
of combatting mosquitoes which we had learned from
the publications of Dr. L. O. Howard, Chief of the
Bureau of Entomology, some years before, and in fact
Walter Reed & Yellow Fever.
3.
the same procedures which Gorgas subsequently used
in Havana had been in use in the neighboring town
of Marianao since the year before, and in fact this war-
fare had been directed officially by Gen. Order No. 6
Hdqrs of Cuba in Dec. 1900. I wrote a polite letter
to Mr. Hendricks as editor of the world work, quoting
authorities for these facts and asking him to pub-
lish my statement in the next issue of the maga-
zine. He did not do so and Gen. Ireland had it
published in the New York Times of Sunday April 27th
1924. We supposed however that he would rewrite this
chapter before the book appeared in the autumn.
But, incredible as it may seem, he did not do so
and, when the biography appeared six months
later, nothing had been corrected, in spite of the fact
that I sent him in May a copy of a letter to me
from Dr. L. O. Howard congratulating me on my
letter to the Times and saying that he had received
in January 1900 a letter from Reed showing that he
knew exactly how the warfare against the mosquito
should be carried out. When the book appeared
with the misstatements all there, I undertook the
review of it which I am sending you at the
Surgeon General's request and he saw to it that
it was widely distributed. I have understood that
Walter Reed & Yellow Fever.
4
this review killed the sale of the book, as it
should have, for nothing would have shock-
ed General Gorgas more than this effort to
filch Reed's laurels. It was reported that Mrs.
Gorgas also protested, but was told that they
were “writing the story of Gorgas and not of
Reed”. I think the trouble with Mr. Hendrick
is that he is more of a newspaper man than a
historian at heart and values the story more
that the facts. The chapter which he publish-
ed in advance in the World's Work and which
he called “Yellow Fever meets its Master” would
have been quite spoiled if he had changed it
to accord with the truth. So he thought he would
take chances on it and let it go. He had plenty
of time to make these corrections as his attention
was called to them in April and the book did
not appear until late in the autumn.

I have inclosed also several other papers for
this file. A list of Incorporation of the Walter Reed
Memorial Assn, organized in 1903, with excerpts
referring to his work. The interest on the fund raised
by this Assn has been used to supplement Mrs. Reeds
pension. The letter from Dr. L. O. Howard refers to the
Review.
